biography:
Laszlo Moholy-Nagy (Hungary/German/United States)
Born in Bacsborsod, Hungary, Laszlo Moholy-Nagy fled to Germany after WW1, where he involved himself with the Dada and Constructivist movements. He began to exhibit and publish prolifically in Berlin and was invited by Walter Gropius to join the Bauhaus School in Weimar where he become widely influential as an artist and educator. With the rise of Nazism he migrated to the USA where he spent his final years teaching at Chicago Institute of Design. His significant theoretical writings include The New Vision (1929) and Vision in Motion (1944). Recent publications include Laszlo Moholy-Nagy (Marseille: Institut Valencia d'Art Moderne, Musees de Maseille, Reunion des Musees Nationaux, Corvina/Flammorion, 1991)
